columns.text: The goal of the task is to calculate the equilibrium payment for a lease.

First, ***what is the equilibrium payment or the break-even lease rent?***

The rent to which the lessee is indifferent in accepting or rejecting a lease or borrowing is called **Equilibrium Lease Rent**. And the equilibrium lease rent has a Net Advantage to Leasing $(\operatorname{NAL})$ of zero.

***What is the Net Advantage to Leasing?*** 

The **Net Advantage to Leasing** $\operatorname{NAL}$ is the Net present value that is calculated when deciding whether to lease an asset or to buy it. 

$\operatorname{NAL}$ is calculated by the difference between the buy options minus the present value obtained from the cash flows. 
See formula $(1)$ for equal annual cash flows.

$$
\begin{equation}
\operatorname{NAL}= NVP = C \hspace{3pt}– \hspace{3pt}CF \times\left(1-\frac{1}{(1+r)^t}\right)          
\end{equation}
$$

Where:

$C$: Cost of the buy option,

$CF$: Annual cash flows, 

$r$: After-tax rate, and;

$t$: the number of years of life.

The decision to buy or lease can be defined after $\operatorname{NAL}$´s calculation:

- If $\operatorname{NAL}= 0$, it depends on the company to decide if is going to buy or lease, considering other advantages of each option.

Now, for the calculation of the **Equilibrium Lease Rent**, we must use the incremental cash flows of the lessor and lessee. Recall that from previous tasks we know the incremental cash flows for both. We show the given data and the tables of the incremental cash flows in the following figure:

Figure 1. Incremental Cash Flow for Lessee and Lessor.

Now, $$ \begin{align*} \text{Annual cash flow}&= \text{After tax lease payment} + \text{Lost depreciation tax shield}\\[10pt] \$1,395,389.40 &= \text{Lease value}\times(1-0.21) + \$252,000\\[10pt] \text{Lease value}&= \frac{\$1,395,389.40 - \$252,000}{(1-0.21)}\\[10pt] &= \frac{\$ 1,143,389.40}{ 0.79}\\[10pt] &= \boxed{\$ 1,447,328.35} \end{align*} $$ ***The lessee will be indifferent about the lease for a Lease value of $\bold{\$ 1,447,328.35}$***.

Now, for what **lease value** will the lessor be indifferent? It would be necessary to repeat the same calculation procedure by using the formula $(1)$, using the incremental cash flow values for the lessor and the given tax rate. In this case, the tax rate for both parties is the same, $(21\%)$, therefore, the result of the calculation will be the same as well. So, ***for a lease value of $\bold{\$ 1,447,328.35}$ the lessor will be indifferent to the lease***.
